												I bought this game mainly because of the tennis part and it feels really good. I'm neither a real tennis nor ping pong player, but both disciplines are great fun and you can choose between "Fun" mode (simplified physics) and "Real" mode ('real' physics).There are different options for audio, playarea, paddle position and so on and the UI is intuitive and easy to use.The ping pong part is nice, whereas Eleven: Table Tennis VR still feels like the best ping pong simulator to me in terms of physics. However there is a career mode, beside partice and online mode, in Virtual Sports, for both tennis and ping pong, which is demanding, AI gets stronger and plays different, and rewarding because you also unlock additional opponents and environments.Tennis works flawless, you will be teleported to a sport where you can reach the ball after your opponent returned it. It only needs ~two matches to get used to. You can also teleport yourself to play close to the net, which is very difficult imho.Graphics are fine, some levels could be a little bit more detailed, antialiasing especially on the ping pong table and both rackets are great though, performance is top. Sound design is appropriate, haptic feedback is good.More content and improvments here and there would be nice, a two vs two mode would be awesome, but overall I can recommend this game in its current state!

Posted: April 17
												Virtual Sports is a worthy videogame and an excellent workout. It's balanced and extremely user friendly, everyone could start to play in seconds in the "Fun" setting (the default one) saving at the same time some consistency and realism in physics, and some depth as well. You can turn that setting for more realism and here the game is way less forgiving, for those who wants more. In any case, it's solid.Table tennis and full tennis share the same kind of progression, some opponents with very different style of playing, three difficulty levels with different locations and a career where you should beat any player in any level. This grant some goals and a gently progression, something than is lacking in almost all similiar games.Tennis is the real star, there are some titles for VR but all of them are or very weak or scifi oriented. If feels very good, you can understand easily when and how to hit the ball, the self teleport mechanics work flawlessy. It's realtively safe as well because it force the player to stay into his small square, but could be easily dangerous for low ceilings as here you can smash at full force and lobs happens.On the other hand, Table Tennis is very good as well. It's natural to compare this one to Eleven or Paddle Up (we shouldn't forget how weak it was Pong Waves when out, the today's game is the end of a very long path mixing two different projects). I'm not a pro so I can't give a final opinion on realism, but it's good enough and support spins and smashes in the proper way. What surely offer as plus is the career, who is missing in almost all other games (we shouldn't forget Ping Pong VR with his arcade mode, fun but with a bad physics). Any opponent at any level play very differently.I would underline something than Virtual Sports could do better as well, even if it's a suggested buy in my opinion. First thing, the overall style is... weird, it's a sort of Wii Sports on acid: it's like is trying to be funny failing the target, too many colours, too many strange items around you, that weird dog. Details are remarkable but style is not. It's noticeable also some lacking in the music, at least some jingles should be added in my opinion. From the gameplay side, devs should add more options like a real torunament (and especially full a tennis match with more sets, longer avaliable now is 1 full set). I would love also for more contents even if it's yet pretty decent.At the end, being "Virtual Sports" and not "Virtual Tennis", I hope (even with DLCs) in more sports of this quality as addictional contents for the future.

												A nice surprise -- very polished and fun.  I've played a lot of Eleven ping pong but I enjoy the single player ping pong in Virtual sports  more.  I actually feel like I'm playing against different opponents in Virtual Sports where in Eleven I feel like I'm playing against invincible robots that sometimes let me win a point here or there.  I'll leave it to others to discuss how realistic the physics are, but for me the physics are close enough to feel like I'm playing ping pong (don't play a lot in real life). Tennis is fun as well -- obviously teleporting tennis is never going to be perfect, but I've played a couple of hours of it already which is more time than I spend in most vive games I purchase.  I highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys racket sports.
